body: I agree with @mcdan that having the application.conf specify the name/key of the configmap that contains the pod spec template is preferable to having the .conf contain the actual template as a string.  I can see this inline design might be more convenient  for standalone, but when deploying to a cluster it is more natural to provide the template in a configmap then having to override a string baked into the invoker docker image via an environment variable to the invoker pod.

This is still possible by referring to env variable in config which in turn is backed by config map entry.

What's not possible is to refer to file via config map based mount. So would the env based approach be sufficient or we need the file based one also?

Accessing the contents of a confgmap in an env var could work fine.  Maybe work through the helm chart change in kube-deploy and see what it would look like?  The thing I'd like to avoid if possible is having to write an awkward string-escaped version of the pod template to change the default value.

A user (subject) may have belong to more than one namespace. Two subjects that share namespace have equal rights to it.

When you create a subject or namespace with wskadmin you are create an identity in the database for them. 

Each namespace has a unique key. When you use wsk property set `--auth` you configure it for that namespace. 

The wsk namespace list operation lists all namespaces authorized by the key. Since it’s bijective you will see only one key. 

Historically a key had access to all namespaces for a subject but this is no longer the case.

When you create a subject or namespace with wskadmin the tool prints out the auth key for it. You can also retrieve it with wskadmin user get. You have to use this AUTH key with REST api calls or wsk cli (`--auth`).

thanks for explaining @rabbah, one more thing - how do you create a namespace? like I mentioned  above another issue is creating namespace the same way you create user (then how can they be two different entities?). Also, I would assume when you create a new user, it will only belong to the guest namespace unless you manually add it to respective namespaces using `-ns` flag (which no longer seems to be working - has it been deprecated?).

When you create a new user they are assigned their own namespace. 

If the flag isn’t working there could be a regression in the docs. This functionality is tested.

```
> wskadmin user create guest1
9e0693f9-ea91-4a94-92ce-7d2f25397dda:...

> wskadmin user create guest2
6276cb16-ccc9-4076-88cd-74465ad03b51:...

> wskadmin user create guest1 -ns sharedspace
b386fb16-7838-425c-9d8a-d8c5ffd32e14:...

> wskadmin user create guest2 -ns sharedspace
f391012d-b6e5-45fe-9080-74aab31a6535:...

> wskadmin user list sharedspace --all
b386fb16-7838-425c-9d8a-d8c5ffd32e14:...	guest1
f391012d-b6e5-45fe-9080-74aab31a6535:...	guest2
```

I don't see a problem with `-ns`.

interesting! I couldn't get the `wskadmin` utility to work initially because the `whisk.properties` environment is not setup by default and I didn't know how to!, so I did gradle build for `wskadmin-next`. I have been using that executable which still doesn't seem to work with `-ns` flag. After i set those environment variable up and tested with existing `/bin/wskadmin`, it works fine.

> I do not understand why users are required to have kubectl, kind, and a Kubernetes cluster just to run tests now.

I have now modified the test to skip run if `KUBECONFIG` env is not defined as part of changes for #4690. With that these test should not cause the build to fail if local k8s is not running

These tests are needed to ensure local integration testing for KubernetesContainerFactory as so far there was not complete test coverage for KCF mode.

> I have been using that executable which still doesn't seem to work with -ns flag

@ali-raza-tariq This was a bug in documented example as `wskadmin-next` argument support bit different formats. More details and updated document now provided in #4692

Can we reopen this?

I am currently looking for a way to run some custom code whenever a container is provisioned with an actual action (both for stem cells and completely new containers). We are providing some extra services as part of our platform that need to be configured with some action-specific data which are however not part of the action itself.

In order to achieve this I would like to SPI ContainerProxy; we could simply subclass it, intercepting the state transitions…
I'd be happy to implement the SPI, but I would like to get some feedback from the openwhisk community as this would be the first openwhisk feature I am working on…

Thanks for your great work on openwhisk!

Oh and I realize this could be implemented using the InvokerReactive; however we would have to basically copy and paste it just changing the `childFactory` field to create our custom proxy instead, which does not seem like the most maintainable way to go ahead with this…

I am not quite sure which logic do you need to execute, but if you just want to add some custom logic in `ContainerProxy` only, I feel it would be better to add functionality to inject some logic dynamically or make it executed dynamically via feature flag.

@Mehervani11 your additions from above contain bearer tokens in clear text in the diagnostic output. I suggest to remove them...

Concerning blackbox actions in general: you cannot just use an arbitrary Docker image as blackbox container. It must support the standard Invoker-runtime interface described here: https://github.com/apache/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions-new.md#action-interface. In summary, the resulting container has to listen on TCP port 8080 and needs to support two "commands" on routes `/init` and `/run`.

From looking over this issue, my expression is that you "just" created an image basing on `openjdk:8-jdk-alpine` and run a standalone Java application. I may be wrong...

If I'm right with my suspicion, this would explain your problems. Your action will just run and write to stdout - but the invoker is not able to init and run the action because it cannot connect to the listening port. So it will give up after the init timeout and report that the action did not init properly.

This document describes how to properly use blackbox / Docker actions on openwhisk: https://github.com/apache/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions-docker.md.

@koraa Sorry for the late response.
I missed your comment in the previous thread.

As I shared in the previous thread, my first impression on this is, one option can be adding a pre-processing hook and/or post-processing hook.
For example, we are creating a container with `ContainerFactory.createContainer`.
If we add an optional processing hook in this method, we can easily add some custom logic.

Since it might not work in your case, it would be great if you share more details about what you need to achieve and where your changes are supposed to be placed.

And I am also curious how other folks think about this.

Hiho!

A hook in createContainer wouldn't work AFAICS as a container may be created without loading an action (creating a stem cell). A hook/event based approach would of course work (we just need to place the hook at the right state transition in ContainerProxy), I am just not sure it would be the most flexible/integrate well with the existing code. Of course if you all decided a hook would be a better I would be happy to implement a hook based solution. Is there any example of a hook based api in openwhisk that I could use as guidance when creating a hook for action provisioning?

Regarding our use case: What kind of information would you like to have? We want to provide platform/runtime level facilities for our actions that need to be provisioned for the specific action; we would not like to change the docker runtime or the action itself to provide these services (for security reasons/running in a separate security enclave & because it is more convenient for the user).

In the specific case we would like to be able to customize how logging is handled on a per client basis  (send log messages in real time to user configured logging sinks).
